contentrichtext.text: :''[[Belisana (spider)|Belisana]]'' is also a spider genus ([[Pholcidae]]). In [[Celtic polytheism]], '''Belisama''' or '''{{lang|el|Bηλησαμα}}''' (''Bēlēsama'') was a [[goddess]] worshipped in [[Gaul]] and [[Ancient Britain|Britain]]. She was connected with lakes and rivers, fire, crafts and light. Belisama was identified with [[Minerva]]/[[Athena]] and has been compared with [[Brigid]]<!-- by whom?-->. She has been claimed to be the consort of [[Belenus]],<ref>[http://www.celtnet.org.uk/gods_b/belisama.html Belisama: a Gaulish and Brythonic goddess (Summer Bright)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> with whom she shared certain attributes. The exact meaning of her name is uncertain, but one possible interpretation is "Very Strong".<ref>Delamarre, Xavier, Dictionnaire de la langue gauloise, Errance, 2003, p. 71.</ref> [[Image:Dédicace de Segomaros (inscription gallo-grecque).png|thumb|300px|RIG G-172 inscription: ''СΕΓΟΜΑΡΟС/ ΟΥΙΛΛΟΝΕΟС/ ΤΟΟΥΤΙΟΥС/ ΝΑΜΑΥСΑΤΙС/ ΕΙѠΡΟΥ ΒΗΛΗ/СΑΜΙ СΟСΙΝ/ ΝΕΜΗΤΟΝ''.]] A [[Gaulish language|Gaulish]] inscription found at [[Vaison-la-Romaine]] in [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur|Provence]] shows that a ''[[nemeton]]'' was dedicated to her:<ref>Michel Lejeune. ''Receuil des Inscriptions Gauloises (RIG)'' '''1''': Inscriptions Gallo-Grèques. G-153.</ref> :''Segomaros Ouilloneos tooutious Namausatis eiōrou Bēlēsami sosin nemēton'' :"Segomarus Uilloneos, citizen [''toutius''] of [[Nîmes|Namausus]], dedicated this sanctuary [''[[nemeton]]''] to Belesama"<ref>Xavier Delamarre (2003). ''Dictionnaire de la langue gauloise.'' Éditions Errance, p.299.</ref> A [[Latin]] inscription from [[Saint-Lizier]], [[Aquitania]] (in antiquity, ''[[Consoranni]]'') associates her with [[Minerva]]:<ref>[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum]] (CIL) '''13''': ''Tres Galliae et Germanae.'' 0008</ref> :''Minervae / Belisamae / sacrum / Q(uintus) Valerius / Montan[us] / [e]x v[oto?]'' ==Placenames== The [[River Ribble]] in England was known by the name Belisama in [[Roman Britain|Roman]] times.<ref>[[Ronald Hutton]] (1991). ''The Pagan Religions of the Ancient British Isles.'' Oxford: Blackwell. p.218</ref> [[Ptolemy]] lists a ''Belisama estuary'' at coordinates which correspond to the mouth of the Ribble. *[[Beleymas]] *[[Bellême]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.roman-britain.org/ptolemy.htm Ptolemy at RomanBritain.org] * [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Periods/Roman/_Texts/Ptolemy/2/2*.html Ptolemy at Lacus Curtius] {{Celtic mythology (ancient)}} [[Category:Celtic goddesses]] [[Category:Fire goddesses]] [[Category:Sea and river goddesses]] [[Category:Crafts goddesses]]
